Step 7: Many to Many

View the Diff

Let‚Äôs add a Team relationship: a Team can have many Employees, an Employee can have many Teams. Let‚Äôs also say a Team belongs to a Department.

id department_id name
1 1 The A Team
2 1 The B Team
3 2 The C Team

To satisfy this many-to-many use case, we‚Äôll need a join model, TeamMembership:

id team_id employee_id
1 1 1
2 2 1
3 3 2

The Rails Stuff üöÇ

Graphiti supports has_many :through:

Finally, we‚Äôll need a new seed file to handle these new associations:

The Graphiti Stuff üé®

Let‚Äôs flesh out our TeamResource:

The trick here is the many_to_many relationship. Let‚Äôs add the reverse as well:

And for good measure:

We can now get all the usual functionality: fetch Employees and their Teams in a single request (or vice versa).

Digging Deeper üßê

The many_to_many relationship is the only one where Graphiti modifies a separate Resource ‚Äúunder the hood‚Äù. When we said many_to_many :employees, the EmployeeResource got a team_id filter, and many_to_many :teams created an employee_id filter on TeamResource.

This is because the logic is more complex than the default use case. We don‚Äôt have a simple WHERE clause; we need to join tables and look at the appropriate primary/foreign keys. If the name of your API association doesn‚Äôt match the name of your ActiveRecord association, try has_many :things, as: :my_activerecord_relationship to make the introspection work correctly - or, write your own filter.

Sometimes you‚Äôll have multiple levels of has_many :through. In this case, a simple many_to_many isn‚Äôt enough - check out our Hopping Relationships Cookbook.

Think hard before reaching for many_to_many. Imagine one Team is the ‚Äúprimary‚Äù Team for an Employee. We‚Äôd add a primary boolean column to the team_memberships table‚Ä¶but that table isn‚Äôt exposed to the API! Consider if there‚Äôs a hidden domain concept there.
